Narcissists can make a great first impression. After that ... How Narcissists Wear Out Their Welcome. ... and the research that shows they're more aware of it than you might think.
There's a better way to get your partner on the same page. Do You or Your Partner Use Guilt Trips to Get What You Want? If you do, research shows that there may be a very high cost.
It often feels impossible to say, "I forgive you." Consider it anyway. 4 Reasons to Give Someone a Second Chance. New research shows how forgiveness can actually benefit you, too.
"All you need is love"? Hardly. 6 Lies That Can Ruin a Relationship. ... and the research that shows how they can be so damaging (and what should replace them).
The old rules are changing. Here's why that's a good thing. Should Women Make the First Move? Research shows how easy it is to overcome old assumptions about gender rules.
Fascinating new research shows how many of us see the physical world in vastly different ways. How Your Size Affects How You Experience the World. Just how high is that wall?
Do you prefer a partner who likes to take charge? This could be the reason. Why Some of Us Seek Dominant Partners. Research shows that relationship choices are more complicated than they appear.

This may be the key to improving your relationship this year. Try This for a Month. It Could Make Your Relationship Stronger Than Ever. Appreciating each other more, research shows, leads to, well, more appreciation.
"Less me, more we," research shows, is a pretty good rule for life. This May Be the Best Prescription for Happiness. ... and the evidence shows it's not just good for extroverts.

Strict diet plans won't make you healthier, or happier. Here's the research that shows why. 3 Reasons You Should Never Go on a Diet (and What to Do Instead) A surprising percentage of us simply can't keep it off long-term anyway.

Do women really see each other as threats? Fascinating new research shows why they might. Do People See Emotions in Your Face That Aren't Really There? Studies of "resting bitch face," and why women see it more than men.

Here's the truth: Almost everything you've heard about detecting deception is a lie. What You Really Need to Know About Spotting Liars. ... and why research shows that you're better at it than you realize.

When your friends and family split up, research shows that you're more likely to as well. Is that a bad thing? Is Divorce Really Contagious? Maybe you're actually at risk of catching something very different.

Are you or someone you know waiting for a partner to change their stripes? Is There Any Hope for Relationships With Narcissists? Research shows what it might take to bring out their empathy and compassion.
Ever feel like something's missing? 7 Reasons You Need to Live a More Awesome Life. New research shows that awe may be the key to unlocking the best in us.
For many people, keeping a partner jealous is a regular strategy. Research shows why. Why Do We Try To Make Our Partners Jealous? What's behind the desire to watch them squirm.
When things aren't going well, here's how to get back on track (and how not to). Feeling Bad? Here's What You Shouldn't Do. Research shows how a common coping strategy backfires.
Are you too picky? Not if you're holding out for these two qualities. The Two Qualities Everyone Needs in a Partner. Without them, research shows, commitment may be too risky.

Research shows that overconfidence can actually be an attractive quality. As for arrogance ... When Dating, Confidence Will Get You Far (But Only So Far) Studies with implications for online profiles and nights out.
You may not be as independent as you imagine. The Truth About What We'll Do To Fit In. New research shows how what we see others do impacts our own decisions.
A good (or bad) suggestion can remake your future, for better or worse. 4 Ways the Power of Suggestion Can Change Your Life. Research shows why self-fulfilling prophecies so often come true.
How do you deal with awkward social situations? Here are 6 tips. 10 Awkward Moments, and 6 Ways to Escape Them. New research shows when things get most awkward, and the best paths to relief.
Do you have friends you can count on? Your life could depend on it. Want to Live Longer? Make Good Friends. Fascinating research shows why there may be nothing more important.

It's not astrology: Research shows that when you were born might actually have an impact on your life, and your future. Why Your Birthday Actually Matters. From intelligence to health to longevity, your birth month has a surprising impact.
Where do you draw the line? When, if Ever, Is It Okay to Lie to Your Partner? Research shows what you can get away with, and what you might not.
Hate to admit you've done something wrong? Here's why that's a problem. Why Confessing Is Good for You. New research shows why taking full responsibility feels better.
Having a cold makes you feel lousy, in more ways than one. The Surprising Psychology of the Common Cold. New research shows just how bad cold and flu season can be for your psyche.

Do you or someone you know hate being "the new guy" or having to mingle with strangers? These tips could help. 6 Ways to Get More Comfortable With Others, and Yourself. New research highlights the core social skills we need to get ahead.
Optimism and positivity are overrated. Here's why. 7 Ways Your Negative Thoughts Can Help You. Research shows why it may be best to imagine the worst.

How you feel about yourself has everything to do with how others feel about you. When You're OK With Yourself, You're Better Together. New research shows the connection between self-esteem and couples' satisfaction.

New research shows what drives some of the most difficult people in your life. Narcissists Need to Love Themselves More, Not Less. Why they react to conflict very differently than others, and why it matters.
Do you know what's behind all of our good-luck charms and irrational traditions? Why We're So Superstitious. Research shows why we believe a lucky hat or chair can make all the difference.
If you're in love, should your costume show it? What Your Halloween Costume Says About Your Relationship. Research shows that our holiday choices may reveal more than we intend.
Fake it till you make it? Like it or not, it works. The Surprising, Infuriating Power of Overconfidence. Research shows that confidence, even without results, can carry people far.
Would it kill you to say thank you? Actually, quite the opposite. The Many Benefits of Showing Appreciation. Research shows that gratitude boosts you and those close to you.
Sometimes, we're just not ready. Here's why. Why First Marriages Fail. Research shows how to form a more mature connection, this time or the next.
When is it okay to take down the mask and show how you really feel? 3 Ways to Know When to Show Your True Emotions. At home, at work, or on the phone, there are calculations you need to make.
Bored? Here's why you should embrace it. The Surprising Benefits of Boredom. Moments of frustration may actually show us a path to success.
When you look at members of the opposite sex, where, and for how long, do you gaze? Who's Checking Out Who? New eye-tracking research shows where our eyes really roam.
Don't take any of your connections for granted. Here's why. Why Other People Are the Key to Our Happiness. Best friend or barista, research shows how our interactions affect our outlook.
When a relationship ends, do you need to erase its online record? How Social Networks Can Inflame Jealousy. Research shows that evidence of past happiness can threaten new partners.
When we judge people by their online profile photos, we're usually wrong. Your Profile Photo Is A Liar. New research shows the weakness of our snap judgments.
Want to feel better? There's an easy way, but few of us do it. Why Doing Good Is Selfish. Research shows that if you want to feel good, help someone else.
Is there something in the air this month? Actually, yes. Why We Feel Lustier in June. Surprising research shows that our interest in sex may peak this month.
Can you spot a liar? Yes, but not in the way you might think. How We Really Detect Lies. New research shows that most of have the skill, but it's not easy.
Want to make a connection? Follow these lab-tested tips. 5 Things We Now Know About Successful Dating. Research shows how you can figure out if what you see is what you'll get.
Have we discovered the key to limiting anger in our relationships? Is Your Partner Hungry for a Fight? Voodoo dolls help researchers show why many couples can't help but argue.
If you think a friend is headed for trouble, research shows you might be right. 5 Signs a Friend’s Relationship May Be on the Rocks. What to look for and why to trust your gut.
Are you pushy or a pushover? How Assertive Should You Be? The Answers Will Surprise You. New research shows who really gets ahead.

clusters.summary: New research on who needs to do it more, and why. New research on what thoughts of a partner can do for you. Surprising new research on why we succeed, and how we blow it. New research reveals what really influences us (and it's not what we think). When you think your partner has disrespected you, how do you react (and how should you)?
messages: A stressful childhood takes its toll in many ways. But new research is highlighting how a chaotic upbringing can also make people stronger in some very specific ways. The Surprising Benefits of a Tough Childhood. "I'd be lying if I didn't acknowledge that misery benefited me in some ways."
Rough day? Try this. 4 Ways to Hit Reset on a Bad Day. New research reveals promising ways to relieve stress and survive breakdowns.
Testosterone doesn't only spur aggression. It may also boost kindness. The Truth About Testosterone. New research reveals the hormone's surprising powers.
Flirting with potential partners can be exciting and enticing. What happens when you settle down? Do Long-Term Partners Need to Flirt More? New research on who needs to do it more, and why.

Death from self-injury is a growing crisis, especially in certain groups. These are the facts. The Startling, Underestimated Crisis of Self-Injury Death. The rates are staggering, according to new research, and action is needed.
Is this your fantasy or is it just not for you? How Many People Are Actually Interested in Threesomes? New research has some surprises.

It's been proven that the color red sparks attraction. New research shows that it also makes us more willing to share intimate information. The Undeniable Romantic Power of Red. ... and why even the color of the paper questions are printed on influences what we'll reveal.
People who grow up to be killers often target animals first, according to some disturbing new research. How Killers Get Their Start. The complex link between animal abuse and serial murder.

What you say after sex is at least as important as what you say before (or during). Here's why. What Your Pillow Talk Reveals About Your Relationship. ... and surprising new research on whether men or women prefer to cuddle.
Travel changes us, new research finds, but not necessarily for the better. An Unexpected Risk of Vacation Travel. New studies on travel and immorality uncover an unsettling connection.

Who engages in BDSM play, and why? A new study of participants provides answers you won't find in the popular books and movies. 50 Shades Happier? The Truth About BDSM Participants. Groundbreaking new research challenges many popular myths about kink.

Do you get chills when you hear powerful music or view an awesome sight? Here's what it may reveal about your personality. The Odd Psychology of Goosebumps. New research on why only some of us are moved to have piloerections.

There are at least 237 unique reasons why people say they have sex. Many have little to do with desire. Why Couples Have Sex Even When One Partner Isn't in the Mood. New research finds that both men and women do it, and usually for the right reasons.

We expect more of our most reliable and disciplined friends. But how does that make them feel? How We Treat the People We Trust Unfairly (Without Realizing It) New research on the downside of having high self-control.

Has your partner ever ignored you to look at his or her phone? Here's why it may be a bigger problem than you think. When You Ignore Your Partner, This Is What They're Thinking. New research on how "phubbing" can torpedo relationships.

When you need someone to do the right thing, or to stop doing the wrong thing, what works best—cash, compliments, or penalties? New research offers some surprising answers. How Can We Get People to Do What They Should? The "cobra effect," and why so many carefully crafted incentives routinely backfire.

Has a partner ever snooped on your phone? And have you ever done it to a partner? Find out how common relationship surveillance really is. In Your Relationship, Who Checks Up on Whom? New research into who's more likely to check a partner's phone, and what it means for their relationship.

Do you consider 20 or 30 texts an hour from a partner to be extreme or abusive? Disturbing new research finds that many people disagree. The Real Impact of Cellphone Use on Relationships. ... and why intense monitoring could become the future norm for couples.

How far would you go to protect your relationship? When You’re in Love With a Beautiful Woman (or Man) New research on how we guard against rivals when we think our partner is more attractive than we are.
All it takes is asking the right question. The Surprising Trick to Finally Getting Someone (or Yourself) to Change. New research on using cognitive dissonance to your benefit.
Is this what you and your partner need? How to Break a Relationship Out of a Rut. New research points to a way to revive romance and connect more deeply,

Being in a committed relationship has a surprising and powerful effect on how you see everyone else. This May Be the Main Reason Why So Many People Don't Cheat. New research on romance, attraction, and temptation.

When the going gets tough, this is how we respond (for better and for worse). Your 9 Top Defense Mechanisms, Revisited. New research proposes that we reconsider knee-jerk reactions and focus on change.

"Locker room" humor has come under fire. New research reveals what's so insidious about it. Does Calling It a Joke Make Sexism More Acceptable? Studies examine how women deal with the ambiguity of sexist humor.

People with no interest in sex don't have a dysfunction, new research argues; they have a wholly distinct sexual orientation. The Surprising Truth About Asexuality. ...and why many asexuals can thrive in happy relationships.

Does your relationship have what it takes to last? The answer may lie in a number you never suspected. Can You Trust Your Partner? Don't Check Their Phone. Check This. New research makes a strong case for considering a factor many new couples ignore.

How much would you pay to avoid embarrassment? How about for an hour of peace and quiet? This Is What People Would Pay to Avoid Sadness or Feel Love. Fascinating new research puts a monetary value on our emotions.

If your partner knew all of your thoughts, would it benefit your relationship, or kill it? How to Stay True to Yourself in Your Relationship (Without Offending Your Partner) New research on the best way to achieve "balanced authenticity."
Just having a backup plan in place may ensure that you'll need it. Here's why. Does Having a Plan B Sabotage Your Plan A? Surprising new research on why we succeed, and how we blow it.
How many potential partners are you keeping on the back burner? The Phenomenon of Back-Burner Relationships. Research reveals the surprising number of partners most of us have on deck.
TGI ... Tuesday? That's right. Here's why. What's the Most Inspiring Day of the Week? Fascinating new research reveals when we're most (and least) likely to be inspired and productive.
The new research on our connection to our phones will shock you. Have You Been Trained by Your Phone? 4 ways to take back control.

There appears to be a connection between income and infidelity, and it may not be good for some couples. Are Wealthy People More Likely to Cheat? New research reveals how money can alter satisfaction with one's partner.
"When love wins, we all win." Why We're Having More Same-Sex Relationships Than Ever. New research on the ramifications of a more accepting culture.

Did you or someone you care about have a difficult childhood? This is how to start the healing. 8 Ways to Begin to Recover from a Tough Childhood. New research leads to new approaches with wide benefits.
Research reveals why our assumptions about married sex are (mostly) wrong. Do Married People Really Have Less Sex? Plus: 7 ways for couples to keep their spark alive.
Do you have an office (or neighborhood) creep? This is why such people really unnerve us. Why Some People Creep Us Out So Much. New research into why your instincts may register oddity as a threat.
Do you tend to keep to yourself? Here's what you may be missing out on. Why You Should Talk to Strangers. Surprising research reveals the benefits of striking up a conversation.

Is sex better in marriage, or between friends with benefits? New research suggests an answer. Are Friends With Benefits as Satisfied as Married Couples? New research with surprising results for both men and women.
Women don't often wear red by accident, according to new research. The Uncanny Power of a Red Dress. ... and why it's all about who one is going to meet.
When you like someone new, do you also start to become more like them? How Falling in Love Changes Who You Are, for Better or Worse. New research on how far we'll go to become similar to a new love.
How well do you remember the first time you met your partner? Was It Really Love at First Sight? New research reveals how we misremember romance.
Are you happier when you're single? New research may suggest why. Why Some People Are Just as Happy Being Single as They Are in a Couple. ... and why it has a lot to do with how we handle conflict.

How do we account for superhuman feats of strength? New research may have an answer. Is Good Really Stronger Than Evil? A clear, and somewhat disturbing, connection between character and physical strength.
You might want to read this before you tell anyone another secret. Who Can You Trust With a Secret? That depends on what it's about, new research finds.

If you happen to enter into a relationship with a psychopath, here's what it might be like. What Happens When a Psychopath Falls in Love. New research into how partners can influence each other, for better or worse.
You have the right to be choosy. Which Are More Powerful, Turn-Ons or Turn-Offs? New research on our true deal-breakers and deal-makers.

Love isn't enough. There are 4 other essential qualities you should be seeking in a partner. How to Pick a Better Boyfriend or Girlfriend. Research reveals the qualities you should really have on your list.
Your success as a couple could very well depend on this question. Can You Just Put the Phone Down? New research on just how we react to smartphone-distracted dates and partners.

Do you long for the good old days? New research finds that indulging in nostalgia can actually be good for you. It's OK to Be Nostalgic. Here's the Science That Proves It. Using the past to beat your present blues.
Can we tell who might turn criminally violent? Is There a 'Criminal Mind'? What Does It Look Like? New research takes us closer to the answers.
You may not believe the link between heavy exercise and higher alcohol consumption. Can Exercising Drive You to Drink? Surprising new research, and a host of possible explanations.
Feeling the urge for some alone time? Resist it. Don't Cancel Your Dinner Plans. They Could Save Your Life. Research reveals why our social lives may be at least as vital to our health as our diets.
How happy you are may depend largely on how old you are. Here's why. At What Age Will You Really Be Happiest? New research into whether youngsters or seniors enjoy life most.
After a breakup, who's more likely to rebound? What's Really Behind Rebound Sex. Research reveals why some of us rush to new partners and others don't.

Has a partner ever ignored you to check their phone? This is what's behind it, and why it can be so damaging. The Routine That Is Ruining More Relationships Every Day. New research into the psychology of phubbing.

Talking about your feelings? That's overrated. Here's what really keeps couples together. 6 Surprising Ways to Improve Your Connection With Your Partner. New research reveals better ideas to maintain successful relationships.

If a partner cheats on you, are you more likely to get mad or get even? Why Some of Us Commit Romantic Revenge (and Others Never Would) New research into those for whom two wrongs really does make a right.
Put down the coffee. There's a better way to get energized. Can a Relationship Give You as Strong a Jolt as Caffeine? New research on what thoughts of a partner can do for you.
Can your mood literally change the way you see the world? Why the Colors You See Aren't Always True. New research reveals what we don't see when we're feeling down.

Your greatest strengths can easily turn into your greatest weaknesses. This is how. Does Your Bright Side Have a Dark Side? Surprising new research on who we really want around when the going gets tough.
We know that yawns are contagious. But new research finds that's not true for everyone. Why Psychopaths Are Immune to Contagious Yawning. A new study casts fresh light on the personality.

Is it hard for you to forgive? Maybe it would be easier if you knew how much it could benefit you. The Surprising Power of Forgiveness. Research reveals that an ability to forgive boosts both emotional and physical healing.

Thinking about doing something wrong? Here's how to make the right call. How to Do the Right Thing (Almost) Every Time. New research reveals a strategy to avoid temptation that you might not have thought of.
New research supports some of the boldest claims of yoga fans. Is This the Best Reason to Finally Start Doing Yoga? Studies find it may have as many benefits as major shifts in diet.

When you think your partner has disrespected you, how do you react (and how should you)? The Right Way to React to Risky Moments in Your Relationship. New research into how we protect our relationships and who succeeds.
Why do so many women have crushes on musicians? New research has the answer. The Evolutionary Advantage of Being a Rock Star. New studies link peacocks and guys with guitars.
Patience really is a virtue. Here's the proof. How to Be More Patient (and Why It's Worth It) Research reveals why waiting just a little longer can lead to real benefits.

No one wants to be the bearer of bad news but sometimes we have to do it. Here's an easier way. 5 Ways to Deliver Bad News With a Minimum of Pain. New research reveals why it's so hard, and a path to making it easier.

Just missing out on something you really wanted isn't the end of the world. In fact, it could just set you up for success. How a (Close) Loss Can Set You Up for a Win. New research into a paradox familiar to anyone who's ever played a slot machine.
When your reputation precedes you, it can make all the difference. How Much Is Your Reputation Really Worth? New research reveals when your reputation matters, and when it doesn’t.
Do you have an honest relationship? 5 Ways to Build Trust and Honesty in Your Relationship. How to be true to yourself and to your partner.
Can you be too confident? New research is certain that you can. The Perils of Being Overconfident. ... and advice on becoming as certain as you need to be.
Caught in the friend zone? New research suggests there may be a way out. When Friends Become Lovers (and Why They Often Don't) It may depend on how realistically you can judge who's 'in your league.'
What would you do if your partner's sexual needs didn't match your own? Are You in the Mood?  New research reveals how partners cope with mismatched desire.
How do other people really see you? The truth may surprise you. Do People Think You're Pushy, or a Pushover? New research reveals how little we understand how we're perceived.
Why do certain people make us uncomfortable? We may finally have an answer. How We Decide Who's Creepy. New research into our 'creepiness detector' explains a lot.
Where you look for a partner has a huge impact on who you'll find. Are You Looking for Love in All the Right Places? Research reveals where we seek long-term love and lurk for hookups.
Having babies (or not) appears to be contagious. But why? Where Do Babies Come From? From Peer Pressure, Apparently. Research reveals how our social networks can influence our major life decisions.

Is it true that the higher your number of sex partners, the less popular you become? Do Promiscuous People Really Have Fewer Friends? New research challenges stereotypes about promiscuity and shaming.
Want to convince someone? Don't roll out facts. Tell a story. Why Feelings Will Always Beat Facts. New research reveals what really influences us (and it's not what we think).

The most important decisions in your life are yours alone, right? Wrong. Are Pregnancy, Marriage, and Divorce Contagious? Research reveals the subtle but surprisingly powerful ways friends influence us.

Looking for love? According to new research, you might want to start by going green. Are Environmentalists Better Romantic Partners? New research into the appeal of eco-conscious people, and their opposites.
Think nothing can change your attitudes? Think again. The Surprising Ways That Simple Actions Can Change Your Mind. New research reveals how your hands and face influence your opinions.
Why are so many people morally opposed to promiscuity? It may not be why you think. The Surprising Source of Our Sexual Morals. New research uncovers an evolutionary basis for some sexual mores.
Is stress really bad for your health? That all depends on you. Why Stress Gets to Us, and How to Make It Stop. New research reveals who stress hurts, and who's immune.
Why do so many people believe horoscopes affect their relationships? Is the Fate of Your Romance Really in the Stars? New research on why we believe.
Is being yourself really the right strategy? Does Your Partner See the Real You? New research on the value of authenticity in romance.
We know when you'll snack more, and it's not when you think. Study: When We Least Expect It, We Overeat. New research suggests a path to smarter eating.
We experience painful emotions almost every day. But this may be the worst. The One Emotion That Really Hurts Your Brain. New research reveals the fearsome impact of humiliation.
Need a break from someone? This could be why. Does Familiarity Really Breed Contempt? Research reveals why we bond with some people but tire of others.
New research finds we don't grow out of our childhood roles as fast as we'd like. Why You and Your Siblings May Still Be Rivals. Parental favoritism has an impact, even decades later.
When you have something serious to talk about, who do you turn to? Why Don't We Confide in the People Closest to Us? New research reveals who we really seek out when we need an opinion.
There's a reason people stay in bad relationships, but it's not why you think. Has Your Relationship Stalled? How Can You Tell? New research reveals how couples go wrong without even realizing it.
Do you avoid conversations on trains, planes, and taxis? Science says you're missing out. Why You Should Talk to Strangers. Research finds surprising benefits from connecting with new people.
We've never been able to narrow our search for a partner like we can today. Is that a good thing? How Do Most of Us Find Love Today? Research reveals major shifts in how we seek partners.
Are smarter people really happier than everyone else? The Surprising Connection Between Intelligence and Happiness. New research answers an old question, although many may not like it.
Which is more important: What you've done, or what you still could do? What's Worth More, Your Past or Your Future? New research upends conventional wisdom about our potential.
Why do pickup artists so often succeed? Now we know. The Psychology of the Pickup Artist. Research casts new light on the strategies employed by cads.
Want to meet new people? First, get your story straight. How to Connect With Anyone. Each of us has a winning story to tell. Here's how to find yours.
Are you a better person in the morning than you are in the evening? When Are You Really at Your Best? New research finds that we're very different people at different times of day.
What do you know about cheating in America? Try this quiz and find out. How Often Do People Really Cheat on Each Other? Decades of research reveal surprising truths about infidelity.

Some Internet trolls are more than annoyances. They're truly scary personalities. Study Concludes: Internet Trolls Are Just Horrible People. New research reports disturbing findings about these characters.
Researchers may have just found another use for marijuana. Is Marijuana the Cure for Loneliness? Surprising results may lead to new treatments, but risks remain.
They say caring is contagious. What about not caring? The Surprising Power of Apathy. New research reveals how others' indifference can affect us.
Do nightmares plague your sleep? There may be ways to put them to rest. 5 Steps to Conquering Nightmares. New research uncovers the link between daytime emotions and nighttime terror.
New research is finally shining a light on why we do what we do after sex. The Surprising Science of Pillow Talk. Post-coital interaction may be crucial to relationship satisfaction.

Are your vegan and vegetarian friends telling the truth about what they eat? A new study raises some doubts. Who's Lying About Not Eating Meat? New research says some of us eat more meat than we claim. Find out who.
Why do we have casual sex? New research says our motivations have changed. Why Men and Women Hook Up Today. Studies seeking differences in male and female motivations uncover a surprise.
What are you hiding? Why We Keep Secrets From Our Partners. New research reveals who keeps the most secrets in relationships, and why.
How far would you go just to mess with someone? How Spiteful Are You? New research, and lessons from history, highlight the importance of spite.
When you line up for summer blockbusters, it may be for deeper reasons than you realize. Why We Really Go to The Movies. New research finds a surprising reason why major movies appeal to us.
Was your first time memorable or regrettable? How We Remember Our First Sexual Experiences. New research reveals significant changes in recent years.
Are selfies destroying your memories instead of saving them? The Hidden Risk of Smartphone Cameras. New research makes the case for keeping your camera in your pocket.
Do you know people who seem to avoid happiness? This may be why. Is Fear of Happiness Real? Research reveals why some of us are afraid of happy events.
Do you believe in love on the rebound? Can a Rebound Relationship Be the Real Deal? New research blows up some common assumptions.
New research reveals why time spent on social networks may be making you less happy. The Hidden Danger of Social Networks. Do you suffer from profile envy?
Stressed? Kiss it out. The Surprising Benefits of Kissing. New research finds major advantages for regular smoochers.
We now know that our sense of smell is vastly better than we ever imagined. Why We Smell Much Better Than We Thought. New research dispels the myth that humans have a poor sense of smell.
The biggest turn-on is a quality most of us have (and anyone can fake). Is Empathy Sexy? New research suggests that, for some of us, good listening is a turn-on.

clusters.summary: The 2 Questions You Have to Ask Yourself About Your Relationship. ... and the 3 questions to ask yourself to get what you need. You can get what you need, if you know how to ask. This Is the One Question You Have to Ask Yourself. But you have to know how to ask.
messages: There's an unexpected key to stronger relationships, and if you don't have it, you may struggle to connect. 13 Questions to Test How Secure You Are in Your Relationship. Do you acknowledge your weaknesses, or run from them?

Answer this one question, and then live your answer. A Surprising Secret to Being Happier, Starting Today. In the stress of the everyday, we can lose sight of what we really care about. Here's how to refocus.

When things go badly, we focus on what's gone wrong. It might be better to do just the opposite. The Single Shift That Could Change Your Life. Need to resolve a crisis? Start by asking the right questions.
Should you stay or should you go? This may help you decide. The 5 Stages of a Relationship's End. ... and 20 questions to help you figure out if you should look for an exit.

If you or someone you know is dealing with the effects of a difficult childhood, this approach could help. 4 Ways to Begin Healing the Wounds of Childhood Trauma. Asking the right questions and changing the script.

A relationship is easy when everything's going smoothly. But how well does it stand up to stress? 5 Questions to Test the Strength of Your Relationship. 1. Are the compromises you make really compromises?
Is your relationship truly flourishing? Here's one way to find out. 12 Questions That Everyone in a Relationship Should Ask Themselves. There's a new way to measure the strength of your connection.

If you don't answer this question for yourself, someone else will try to impose an answer on you. This Is the One Question You Have to Ask Yourself. ... and how to use your answer to make your most important life choices.

After a rough breakup (or several), how can you tell when you're ready to try again? These questions will help you figure it out. 15 Questions to Help You Decide If You're Ready to Date Again. Are you feeling good enough about yourself to go back "on the block?”
Are you ready to tie the knot? These essential questions can help you figure it out. 7 Questions You Have to Ask Each Other Before You Commit. 4. Do you know each other's triggers and traumas?

Can we save ourselves from surveillance and hacking? A founder of the field insists that we still can. The Case for Radical Privacy. "How do you want to live in five or 10 years? That's the question."
How much intimacy can you handle? 6 Questions to Test Your 'Intimacy Quotient' ... and what to do if you're just pseudo-intimate.

Friends, family, and even strangers really do want to help you. You just need to know how to ask. 7 Effective Ways to Ask for Help (and Get It) 1. Make it clear that you've already tried to help yourself.

Marriage is such a better deal for men, some experts wonder why women even bother. Is Marriage Worth It For Women? There are some very good reasons why most divorces are the woman's idea.

If a new partner's "number" is especially high, is that a deal breaker? Does Having a High Number of Past Partners Help You Find a Steady Relationship? New research on how men and women judge each other's sexual history.

7. A male acting like a man is nothing more and nothing less than having the courage to be true to himself. 7 Things Men Need to Know About Their Mental Health. ... and why it's so vital to the people who rely on them.

Men and women who marry only for the money often demand a lot when the relationship ends. Are they entitled to it? What Does a 'Gold Digger' Deserve? How the concept of unjust enrichment plays out in divorce court.

New guidelines suggest that all women of child-bearing age may need to stop drinking. Here's one response. Do All Young Women Really Need to Stop Drinking? "You know what a beer is? Stay away from it!"
Men and women get jealous in very different ways, and social media doesn't help. Do You Know What Makes Your Partner Jealous? ... plus 3 takeaways that could help you avoid trouble.
When you're dating, are turn-ons or turn-offs more important to you? The Top 9 Relationship Deal Breakers. ... and the research that reveals what they mean for men and women.
This is really why men eat more meat than women. What It Means to Eat 'Like a Man' (or Woman) ... and the mental block we need to overcome to eat healthier.

Men act in some curious ways when women are around, maybe none more curious than this. Do Men Really Eat 93 Percent More When Women Are Around? ... and if the research is right, then what explains it?

Troubling new research finds that when men get angry, they get results. As for women ... Why Don't We Trust Angry Women? A study shows that women may be taken less seriously than men when they behave in exactly the same way.

It's not about sex, housework, the kids, or even snoring. But it's at least as hard to fix. The Number One Complaint of Married Men (and Some Women) What's welcome during the honeymoon can be divisive down the line.

We think that women prefer 'macho' men, at least for one-night stands. But is that really the whole story? Do 'Macho' Men Get All the Attention in the Dating Pool? New research into how we really choose our partners.
We need to stop poking fun at "bromance" right now. Here's why. Why Do We Make Fun of Men Who Hang Out Together? Friendships are vital for everyone's health, men's included.

Is your greatest sexual regret something you did, or something you didn't do? Why Men and Women Have Different Sexual Regrets. New research finds striking gender differences, regardless of sexual preference.
Why do men swear more than women? This could be the answer. Why Men Are the More Vulgar Sex. Plus: Which swears are dropped most often on social media.
Playfulness may be a survival skill, and an indicator of sexiness. The Underrated Importance of Being Playful, in Life and Romance. ... and the very different signals it sends to men and women.
Have men become less interested in casual sex (and women more interested)? 5 Signs That Men and Women Are Converging. These are not your grandparents' gender norms. Not even close.
You feel like a different person when you're in love, probably because you are. What Does Being in Love Do to Your Brain? ... and why the research shows it might affect men and women differently.

A fascinating new survey reveals what men really value in their wives and their daughters. Does Becoming a Dad Make Men More Sexist or Progressive? ... and how could their biases impact the next generation of women?
The data is clear: A relationship can do a lot for a guy. Why Relationships Are a Much Better Deal for Men. Discover why a body of research shows that coupled men live happier and longer.
Why can't some women take a compliment? The Real Reason Some Women Put Themselves Down. It's not low self-esteem. It's a more subtle strategy.
You can learn a lot about someone from the way they use their hands. What Do Your Hands Reveal About You? ... and why do men and women tend to use very different hand gestures?
Are you more (or less) jealous than your partner? Who Gets More Jealous, Men or Women? A study sheds new light on an ancient question.
For certain people, this is reason to brag, not that they would. The One Quality We Know Makes People More Attractive. New research on a trait both men and women prize.
When things go bad, who's more likely to walk away? Now we know. Who Is More Likely to Leave a Bad Relationship? … and why men and women would both be happier if this difference went away.
On the dating scene? Protect yourself from these men and women. How to Spot a Manipulator. 10 ways to ID pickup artists, and fend them off.
Can men and women really just be friends? Now we know. Attraction, Just Between Friends. New research reveals what really happens when Harry meets Sally.
How much more attention do men pay to women in heels? The answer is pretty shocking. The Surprising Power of Women in High Heels. Creative research reveals a striking response.
Is being in a couple more important to men or women? Do Men and Women Get the Same Things From a Relationship? Research finds that romance offers men and women very different benefits.
There's at least one crucial difference between male and female personalities. What Men and Women Do Differently and Why It Matters. How we read each other's moods varies widely, and unfairly.
Men are from Earth. Women are from Earth. End of story. 6 Myths About Men, Women, and Relationships. Research proves that we're a lot more alike than most of us think.
Are vegans "real men"? Find out how we really rate our partners' diets. Is Our Diet Sexist? Outdated ideas about gender may affect our health.
Are you a romantic? Should you be? Who's Really More Romantic, Men or Women? It may not be who you think. Here's why.
How many of these apply to you (or your partner)? 6 Ways Men and Women Are (Mostly) Different. We both want it all. Beyond that, research finds, we have less in common.
Do men really avoid commitment? New research has the answer. Who Craves Relationships More, Men or Women? The origins, and accuracy, of a long-held stereotype.
Have you ever dated (or been) a player? Ambivalent Men, and the Women Who Love Them. Here's why you'll never win with someone who's emotionally unavailable.
Are men really hard-wired for sexual harassment? The Real Reason Sexual Violence Is So Widespread. An anthropologist challenges the idea that we're no better than animals.
Who's happier, men or women? Meet the Least Happy People in America. A new survey reveals who fits the profile. An expert explains why.
How much do you need to know about a partner's romantic history? Do You Give Out Your Number? Men and women may see their sexual histories very differently.
Can men and women truly just be friends? Now we know. Attraction, Just Between Friends. New research reveals what really happens when Harry meets Sally.
What do women want from men? Now we know. 4 Smarter Ways Men Can Woo Women. Research shows why, in romance, nice guys don't always finish last.
What do men consider the ideal female body? Not the one you think.  What Men Want. Surprising research into what men naturally sense and why it matters.
Who is more likely to end a relationship, men or women? Do Men or Women File for Divorce More Often? There are different theories about this finding. What's yours?
Who's more interested in threesomes, men or women? Would You Have a Threesome with Two Opposite-Sex Partners? Men are much more into FMF threesomes than women are into MFM threesomes.
Maybe she’s just insecure. Why Do Women Fake Orgasms?

Men get bored after just 26 minutes at the mall, while women can shop four times as long. Sound like anyone you know? Here’s the real reason why we can’t go shopping together. Why Men Don't Like Shopping and (Most) Women Do. The origins of our attitudes toward shopping.
War of the women: Sure, men may literally fight over mates, but women have their own playbook. Feminine Foes. In the sexual trenches, women's tenacity and competitiveness rivals men's.

How could an hourglass figure relate to a woman’s success as a mother? In more ways than you think. Eternal Curves. Men “know” something significant about women’s bodies that women don’t. And it all has to do with nature’s mandate to produce children with the...
"Women are far braver than stereotypes of male courage might lead us to believe...Courage is as feminine as it gets." Women Are Braver Than Men. New science suggests we need to rethink courage.

"While age seems paramount in the abstract (all things being equal, men desire younger women, and women desire older men), in practice, when two people actually go on a date, the age difference might not have as much importance as physical attraction and a compatible personality." When It Comes To Dating, Do Age Differences Matter? A recent study lends insight into age differences in romantic relationships.

http://www.psychologytoday.com/blog/insight-therapy/201306/if-only-gender-differences-in-sexual-regret. If Only... : Gender Differences in Sexual Regret. Women regret sex without relationships. Men regret relationships without sex.
Only looking: Men, women, and "romantic window shopping" http://ow.ly/i1EF1. Why Do Women Tend to Refrain from Romantic Window Shopping? Why Don't Men Like Window Shopping?

Most men prefer a particular shape of women's bodies—one different than what women tend to think of as ideal. Here's why. Eternal Curves. Men know something significant about women's bodies that women don't. And it all has to do with nature's mandate to produce children with the...

Do men and women think differently about sex? Sure. But not as much as you probably think. Women from Venus? Men from Mars? The Real Sexual Gender Divide. Men and women feel more similar about sex than most people imagine.

clusters.summary: New research shows why the reasons you do it make all the difference. Do women think about sex less, and reject casual sex more? But do you know what it does for your sex life? 4 Common Myths About Sex and Desire (and the Surprising Truth) Think it's abnormal to desire a dominant partner (or to be one)? The new research on casual sex may surprise you.
messages: The data is clear: American couples are having less sex. Here are 5 reasons why. Why So Many Couples Are Having Less Sex. Experts blame culprits including politics and better TV.
Better sex has little to do with devices, positions, or workouts. It has everything to do with this. 10 Steps to a Better Sex Life. 9. Don’t have sex when you don’t want to.
The key to great sex isn't technique. It's this. The Surprising Secret to a Better Sex Life (and Relationship) ... and the 3 questions every couple must ask each other.

Sure, it can increase your flexibility. But do you know what it does for your sex life? The Growing Evidence That Yoga Improves Sex. A surprising bonus benefit, at least for women, to go with all the other things yoga can do for your health.
Is there a secret to keeping things from getting "complicated"? The Sex Test. Why do so many relationships derail when sex enters the equation? It may not be why you think.

Do teens who start having sex early really face psychological risks? New research finally provides some answers. Is There a Right Age to Begin Having Sex? The risks, and some potential benefits, of having one's sexual debut unusually early or late.

Some long-held assumptions about men's libido, infidelity, and promiscuity just don't hold up to scrutiny. (But a couple do.) The 4 Most Common Myths About Men and Sex. Do men really think about sex more than women do? No, but they seem to think they do.

What happens after sex may reveal more about your relationship than what happens during sex. The Psychology of Sexual "Afterglow" ... and why the good feelings might last longer for some couples than for others.
Is "make-up sex" a myth? How Anger Can Ruin a Couple's Sex Life. Ever been told, "Don't go to bed angry"? This is why.
Sex can make you smarter, and that's just for starters. 7 Reasons You Should Have More Sex. Intimacy with your partner satisfies a host of vital psychological needs.
Do young people today really have more casual sex than their parents did? The Shocking Truth About Hook-Ups and Casual Sex. New research disproves a range of myths about modern sex.
It has little to do with their parents, or their sex-ed classes. The Top Reasons Why Teens Decide Not to Have Sex. ... and why so many are so proud of their choice.
1. Men always crave sex more than women do. 4 Common Myths About Sex and Desire (and the Surprising Truth) Think it's abnormal to desire a dominant partner (or to be one)? Think again.

Research into sexual fantasies proves that most of us are more interested in "atypical" sex than we admit. When It Comes to Sex, What's Really 'Normal'? The reality, some experts argue, is that 'vanilla' sex may be the least 'normative' of all.

A surprising number of adults live happily, and have great relationships, without ever thinking about having sex. Living Happily Ever After, and Never, Ever Having Sex. Individuals with no interest in sex argue that they represent a fourth sexual orientation. The experts say they may be right.
When it comes to sex, is more always better? How Many Sex Partners Does It Take to Be Happy? A survey of recent research examines the causes and consequences of a person’s number of sexual partners.
Are young people today having sex earlier than ever? Here are the facts. The Truth About Teens and Sex. …and the one factor tied to virginity loss a stunning two years earlier than average.

Contrary to popular belief, the younger generation appears to be having less sex than their parents did at the same age. But why? Why Young People Aren't Having as Much Sex as They Used To. Millennials and their younger siblings may be too distracted, too nervous, or just lacking a place to hook up.
This is what's really happening when we swipe right. The Surprising Truth About Why People Use Tinder. "Hookup" apps aren't just about sex. For some, they're not even about sex at all.
When one partner wants sex more than the other, is there any way for them both to be happy? Why So Many Couples Struggle With Sex. It may be time to start discussing some taboo subjects.

Often, it's not just about the sex, although it can ruin sex for a couple. The Reasons Someone Looks at Porn Matters. This Is Why. New research reveals the risks of getting hooked, especially for certain reasons.
When it comes to sex, is more always better? A new study has an answer. Would More Sex Really Make You and Your Partner Happier? What happens when couples try to double their sexual frequency.
A fleeting hook-up isn't always a bad thing. Is Casual Sex Bad for Your Mental Health? New research shows why the reasons you do it make all the difference.

Can a relationship survive on "charity sex" and "peace-keeping sex"? 3 Reasons Couples Might Have Sex Even Though Only One Really Wants To. The pros and cons of being there for each other, no matter what.

Are you as close as you think you should be? 8 Common Myths (and 1 Eternal Truth) About Intimacy in Relationships. How important is sex? Will your marriage be just like your parents'? And can you go to bed angry?
Do couples who share their chores actually have less sex? Is Doing Housework a Turn-On? New research on whether couples who share the load spend more (or less) time in bed.
We know that sex after a split is common, but is it ever a good idea? Should You Ever Have Sex With Your Ex? Act Two brings serious emotional risks for both partners.
It may be time to schedule some sex with your partner. How to Keep a Relationship From Growing Cold. ... in a culture that puts up so many roadblocks.
Do hookups come with an emotional cost, or a psychological benefit? What Are the Psychological Effects of Casual Sex? Intriguing new research reveals who benefits, and who doesn't.
What do you think is a "normal" frequency of sex? Are You Having Enough Sex? What the research has to say about what we want, and what we get.
Partners who wish they had sex more often may be facing one of these 4 challenges. 4 Reasons You're Not Having Sex. It's rarely about desire alone.

Some insist sex addiction is real and demands attention. Others dismiss it as an excuse for cheating. Where do you stand? Is Sex Addiction Really an Addiction? 5 reasons why many experts refuse to accept that it's a true disorder.
Want to have more and better sex? 6 Reasons Why Married People Should Have Better Sex Lives. Much of what you've been led to believe about married sex is probably wrong.
Will having more sex make you happier? A new study has some answers. Could Having Sex Twice as Often Actually Make You Less Happy? New research may upend some long-held assumptions.
Worried that your sex life doesn’t live up to Hollywood ideals? Don’t be. Here's a better model. Is Perfect Sex Possible? Why realistic expectations can lead to greater satisfaction.
What are the real emotional risks of hookups? How Casual Sex Can Affect Our Mental Health. We're finally learning what hookups do to our psyche, for better and worse.
Too busy? Don't feel sexy? You're missing out, in more ways than one. The 5 Excuses We Need to Stop Making About Sex. Sex is more than just sex. When we let it drop out of our lives, there's a cost.
Make-up sex happens. Here's why. The Truth About Make-Up Sex. Research into the connection between conflict and desire.
We may enjoy sex, but do we really need it? Sex Drive? There's No Such Thing. A new book casts doubt on some cherished assumptions.
Pity sex happens. Here's why. The Many Complicated Reasons We Have Sex. Pity sex, charity sex, and other hookups with people we don't love.
Do we misunderstand people who enjoy casual sex? Does Wanting Casual Sex Really Mean Not Wanting Love? Challenging assumptions about those who seek hookups, and those who don't.
How often do we get distracted during sex? See what the research says. Why We Can't Stay Focused During Sex, and Why It Matters. Are you guilty of 'spectatoring'?
The new research on casual sex may surprise you. Which of Us Craves Casual Sex More? Diffrences in gender and attractiveness can impact desire, in some of us.

When a man loses interest in sex, it often has little to do with his partner. Here's what's really going on. The 4 Hidden Reasons Some Men Don't Want Sex. Psychological insights into the causes of low male libido.
A new study overturns long-held assumptions about housework and sex. Do Couples Who Share Housework Really Have Less Sex? Research shows what actually happens when men start cooking and cleaning.
Is make-up sex better than not-fighting-in-the-first-place sex? Does Fighting Really Energize Your Sex Life? New research puts an old question to the test.
Has the one-night stand gone out of style? New research has the answer. What Type of Casual Sex Are People Really Having? Who do we hook up with? Studies find a potentially major shift.

Our emotional reactions to casual sex are far from black and white. After a Hookup, Are More of Us Happy & Hopeful or Used & Confused? A new study identifies 4 distinct groups. Which best describes you?
Do women think about sex less, and reject casual sex more? Hardly. 6 Myths About Female Sexuality and Why They're Wrong. Research disproves outdated ideas about the female libido once and for all.
Our feelings and bodies can change. Our sex lives don't have to suffer. Is Something Getting in the Way of Your Sex Life? Don't shut down. Follow this advice.
Everything you thought you knew about sex may be wrong. Sex Isn't Rocket Science. It's Much More Complex. Get ready to radically rethink desire, marriage, fidelity—and hotel rooms.

When one partner longs for sex and the other doesn't, it's a crisis that demands immediate action. 4 Myths About Sexual Desire in Relationships. The truth about sex within couples, and tips to reignite the flame.
Do we have more hookups today than ever before? Is Casual Sex on the Rise in America? First-of-its-kind research delivers some surprises.
Have you ever regretted a hookup? After Casual Sex, Do We Feel a Rush or Regret? The research contradicts common assumptions.
The world's funniest women are smart, quick, and have no taboos. You got a problem with that? Are Women the Funnier Sex? Sarah Silverman, Joan Rivers, and more share the strength of female stand-ups.

Are you obligated to have sex with your long-term partner? If not, are they entitled to seek it elsewhere? Does a Sexless Relationship Justify Infidelity? Confronting a third-rail issue that challenges many couples.
Is casual sex good for your psyche? The research may surprise you. Are Hookups Psychologically Healthy? After the pleasure, there can be renewed confidence or profound regret.
Do you judge women more harshly for having casual sex? Is the Sexual Double Standard Going Away? Not necessarily, but it may be evolving.
The fleeting hook-up isn't always a bad thing. Is Casual Sex Bad for Your Mental Health? If you do it for the wrong reasons.
If you're ready to learn something about your sex life, ask yourself these two basic questions. How to Think About Your Sex Life. Discovering new portals to more meaningful sex.
How many sex partners do people have before settling down? How many should we? Is it Good or Bad to Sow Your Wild Oats? How many premarital sex partners should you have?
Intimacy might be considered to be the "nutritional value" of sex. Is junk sex as bad as junk food? On healthy life and healthy romantic relationships.

"No amount of admiration, affection, conversation, or sex will ever be enough to satisfy a person whose internal compass does not point to joy." http://ow.ly/ldFU8. The Pleasure Trap. The important difference between pleasure and joy.

People who are insecure are more likely to equate sex with romantic love. 

What else does your personality reveal about your sex life? Personality in the Bedroom. What we know from 20 years of research on sexuality and personality.

Check out PT's first cover story of the new year! 12 Rude Revelations About Sex. In order to transcend the discomfort that sex typically stirs, you may need to radically rethink desire, marriage, fidelity, and much more.
Sex can drive us to do things beyond all reason. But why? Sex and the Single Primate. A pretty face can lead men to take greater risks.

[2005] "When Susan was the age of many of her students, she dominated the New York Open chess competition. At 16 she crushed several adult opponents and landed on the front page of The New York Times. The tournament was abuzz not just with the spectacle of one pretty young powerhouse: Susan's raven-haired sister Sophia, 11, swept most of the games in her section, too. But the pudgy baby of the family, 9-year-old Judit, drew the most gawkers of all. To onlookers' delight, Judit took on five players simultaneously and beat them. She played blindfolded." (Carlin Flora, Psychology Today) The Grandmaster Experiment. The world's first female grandmaster was ready to deliver her regular Thursday-night lecture.
